Fig. 1 The schematic representation of the catalytic activity test device. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 The XRD pattern of HPMo, Cu(3)-HPMo and Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 The denitration efficiency of HPMo/TiO2, Cu/TiO2 and Cu(x)-HPMo/TiO2(x = 2,3,4). Reactants: 500 ppm NO, 500 ppm NH3 and 8 × 104 ppm O2 in N2. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 15,000 h−1. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 The effects of SO2 on the catalytic activity of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 and Cu/TiO2. Reactants: 500 ppm NO, 500 ppm NH3, 0−600 ppm SO2 and 8 × 104 ppm O2 in N2. The gas hourly space velocsity (GHSV) was 15,000 h−1. The test temperature was 200℃. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 The NH3-TPD pattern of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 and Cu/TiO2. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 The FT-IR spectra of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2. (a) catalyst without SO2, (b) catalyst with 600 ppm SO2 Fig. 6 Fig. 7 The TG spectra of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2. (a) catalyst without SO2, (b) catalyst with 600 ppm SO2 Fig. 7 Fig. 8 The effects of water vapor on the catalytic activity of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 and Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2(s). Reactants: 500 ppm NO, 500 ppm NH3, 0−8 × 104 ppm H2O and 8 × 104 ppm O2 in N2. The gas hourly space velocsity (GHSV) was 15,000 h−1. The test temperature was 200℃. TiO2(s) refers to the carrier with small specific surface area. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 The effects of SO2 and water vapor on the catalytic activity of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2. Reactants: 500 ppm NO, 500 ppm NH3, 4 × 104 ppm H2O, 200 ppm SO2 and 8 × 104 ppm O2 in N2. The gas hourly space velocsity (GHSV) was 15,000 h−1. The test temperature was 200 ℃. FT-IR and TG spectra: catalyst with 200 ppm SO2 and 4 × 104 ppm H2O. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 The schematic diagram of the DFT computational model. All energies and bond lengths were given in kJ·mol−1 and Å. Fig. 11 Fig. 12 The molecular structure and energy states of SO2 adsorbed on O atoms (a, b), Lewis acid sites (c,d) and Brønsted acid sites (e, f) of CuO(1 1 1). Graphical abstract The selective catalytic reduction with NH3 (NH3-SCR) catalyst for de-NO x is usually inhibited by SO2 and water vapor at low temperature. The copper-doped phosphomolybdic acid (Cu-HPMo) was supported on titanium dioxide (TiO2) and a novel catalyst Cu-HPMo/TiO2 with good resistance to SO2 and water vapor was developed. Experimental results show that the best catalytic activity of Cu-HPMo/TiO2 was obtained at the Cu/Mo molar ratio of 3. The denitration efficiency over the Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 catalyst was approximately 99 % at 200 ℃ and remained almost constant in the presence of 200 ppm SO2 and 4 × 104 ppm H2O. Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 with strong surface acidity suppressed SO2 adsorption and showed good SO2 resistance. SO2 in the gas phase diffused more strongly at the concentration of 600 ppm than at 400 ppm. The catalytic activity of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 decreased in the presence of 600 ppm of SO2 and the FT-IR and TG results indicated that copper sulfate was formed. Density functional theory (DFT) calculation was used to study the adsorption states of SO2 and H2O on the catalyst surface, and the results indicated that SO2 could not form chemical adsorption on the HPMo surface. Based on the results of experiments, characterization and DFT calculation, the core-shell structure of active components was speculated. This structure was related to the anti-sulfur and anti-water properties of Cu-HPMo/TiO2. Keywords NH3-SCR NOx Phosphomolybdic acid DFT Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NO x ) emitted from industrial flue gases form iron and steel sintering fumes and coke oven fumes are a major pollutant that give rise to environmental problems [1–3]. The selective catalytic reduction with NH3 (NH3-SCR) technology is an effective method for controlling NO x emission from fixed sources, and the V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst is widely used in the NH3-SCR process [4,5]. The temperature of the industrial flue gases from iron and steel sintering fumes and coke oven fumes is usually between 130 ℃ and 240 ℃. The optimum operating temperature of the V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst used for the coal-fired flue gas de-NO x is usually between 300 ℃ and 400 ℃, so the V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst is not suitable for the low temperature de-NO x in the industrial flue gas [6]. Moreover, the catalytic activity of V2O5-WO3/TiO2 is severely inhibited by SO2 and water vapor as temperatures below 250 ℃ [7–9]. Several low-temperature NH3-SCR catalysts with different metal oxides, supports and polymetallic active component have been developed by researchers [10–12]. However, the resistance to SO2 and water vapor of these catalysts has not shown pronounced improvement. To maintain the catalytic activity of the catalysts, the industrial flue gas is usually heated to 280 ℃ prior to its introduction to the NH3-SCR system, resulting in high energy consumption and operating cost. Accordingly, the development of low-temperature NH3-SCR catalysts with excellent SO2 resistance and water resistance is urgent. The catalytic activities of low-temperature NH3-SCR catalysts are generally inhibited by SO2 and water vapor through competitive adsorption, the deposition of (NH4)2SO4 and metal sulfates [13,14]. It is well-known that SO2 in the flue gas is hardly oxidized to SO3 by O2 in the absence of the catalyst. (NH4)2SO3 generated by the reaction of SO2 and NH3 decomposes at temperature above 70 ℃. SO2 is an acidic gas, so that the adsorption of SO2 on the catalyst surface will be hindered by increasing the surface acidity of the catalyst, which could promote the sulfidation resistance of the NH3-SCR catalyst. Similar conclusion has been obtained by Li et al. [15,16]. The catalytic activity of low temperature NH3-SCR catalyst is inhibited by water vapor because of the competitive adsorption between the reactants and the water vapor on the surface of the catalysts [17–19]. In addition, some studies have indicated that a small amount of water molecules can form hydroxyl groups (Brønsted acid site) on the catalyst surface through chemical adsorption to promote more NH3 molecules to participate in the NH3-SCR process [20]. Adsorption and desorption equilibria of water vapor exist on the catalyst surface and the proportion of the active sites occupied by the water molecules is related to the temperature [21]. Accordingly, the amount of the active sites unoccupied by water vapor will increase with increasing the specific surface area of the catalyst at the constant temperature. Heteropoly acids (e.g., phosphotungstic acid, phosphomolybdic acid, silicotungstic acid) are solid oxygen-containing polyacids with excellent electron transport capability and oxidation-reduction property [22–24]. Gómez-García and Labaki [25,26] pointed out that SO2 was hardly adsorbed on phosphotungstic acid (HPW) for the generation of sulfate. Ren et al. [27] found that the activity of the HPW catalyst remained almost unchanged in the presence of 200 ppm SO2 and 1 × 105 ppm water vapor. Molybdenum has several valence states and is widely used as an active component in catalysts. Phosphomolybdic acid is a heteropolyacids with strong surface acidity and superior redox property and is a promising catalyst for low temperature de-NO x performance. While phosphomolybdic acid (HPMo) has been developed for organic synthesis and desulfurization by some researchers, it has been rarely investigated for SCR catalysis [28–31]. In this work, the copper-doped phosphomolybdic acid (Cu-HPMo) was supported on titanium dioxide and a novel Cu-HPMo/TiO2 catalyst was developed. The effect of SO2 and water vapor on its NH3-SCR performance was investigated. The physical and chemical properties of Cu-HPMo/TiO2 were characterized by XRD, NH3-TPD, FT-IR, TG, BET, FE-SEM and HRTEM. Additionally, the competitive adsorption of NO, NH3, SO2 and H2O was investigated by density functional theory (DFT). The present work provides a new strategy for optimizing resistance to SO2 and water vapor of the catalyst to improve the low temperature de-NO x performance. Materials and methods Preparation of catalysts All of the reagents used in this study were of analytical grade and were provided by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. First, phosphomolybdic acid (0.55 g) and certain amount of copper nitrate (the Cu/Mo molar ratios were 2, 3 and 4) were dissolved in distilled water (30 mL). The obtained solution was then stirred at 40 °C for 1 h. Subsequently, the mixture was heated in a water bath (85 °C) for 4 h and then it was dried at 105 °C for 3 h. Then, the solid was calcined at 350 ℃ for 3 h and the active component Cu(x)-HPMo was obtained (x = 2, 3 and 4). Moreover, phosphomolybdic acid (1.0 g) and copper nitrate (1.0 g) were separately dissolved in distilled water (30 mL). The active component HPMo and Cu species were respectively prepared according to the preparation process of Cu(x)-HPMo. The TiO2 with specific surface area of approximately 300 m2/g was used as the support. For all of the catalysts, the loading of the active components was 10 wt.%. According to the condition in previous paragraph, the active component (0.30 g) and TiO2 (2.70 g) were successively dissolved in distilled water (30 mL), stirred, heated in water bath, dried and calcined. Finally, the Cu(x)-HPMo/TiO2 (x = 2, 3, 4), HPMo/TiO2 and Cu/TiO2 were obtained. Catalytic activity test The Cu(x)-HPMo/TiO2 samples (0.40 g) were tested for catalytic activity in a fixed bed reactor (8 mm inner diameter). A schematic representation of the catalytic activity test device is presented in Fig. 1 . The simulated flue gas consisted of 500 ppm NO, 500 ppm NH3, 8 × 104 ppm O2, 0–600 ppm SO2, 0–8 × 104 ppm water vapor and balanced with N2. The water vapor in the flue gas was generated by injected some distilled water into preheater (120 ℃). The total gas flow rate was 100 mL/min and gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was approximately 15,000 h−1. The concentrations of NO x were measured using the MRU Vario Plus flue gas analyzer. The denitration efficiency was defined as (1) η(%)= c NO x in - c NO x out c NO x in ×100 where c NO x in and c NO x out were the concentrations of NO x in the flue gas at the inlet and outlet, respectively. Catalyst characterization To determine the main crystalline phases in the active components of catalyst, X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were carried out with a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ =0.154 nm) for 2θ = 10° - 80° with a step size of 7.2°/min. Temperature programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) was carried out using an automatic chemical adsorption analyzer (Quantachrome Autosorb IQ-AG) to analyze the surface acidity of the catalyst. In the NH3-TPD tests, the mass of each catalyst sample was 0.30 g. To determine whether Cu-HPMo/TiO2 was poisoned by SO2 and water vapor, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) (Thermo Nicolet Corporation Nicolet 6700) and thermogravimetric (TG) analysis (DTG-60 H) were conducted. In the TG tests, the catalyst samples were heated from room temperature (RT) to 800 ℃ at a rate of 10 ℃/min with N2. To investigate the relationship between the water resistance and the catalyst specific surface area, the BET surface areas of the catalysts were tested by N2 adsorption and desorption using a V-Sorb2008MP gas sorption analyzer (Beijing, China). Morphology analysis of the catalyst was conducted by high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEM-2100 F) and field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, JEOLJSM-6380LV). DFT calculational methodology In recent years, density functional theory (DFT) has attracted much attention due to its ability to analyze the gas adsorption and reaction path on the catalyst surface from the molecular perspective [32,33]. In this work, DFT calculation was performed with the local density approximation (LDA-VWN) of the exchange-correlation functional in the Dmol3 module of Materials Studio 2018 [34,35]. Double Numerical plus polarization (DNP) basis set was used for the valence electrons [36]. The electronic iterations convergence criterion was 1.00 × 10−6 eV and the DⅡS (smearing = 0.005) method was used to accelerate SCF convergence [37].The following equation was used to calculate the adsorption energy (Eads). (2) Eads=E(molecule∕cluster)-Emolecule-Ecluster Here, Emolecule and Ecluster were the energies of the molecule and the cluster prior to adsorption, and E(molecule∕cluster) was the total energy of the system after adsorption. The adsorption was found to be an exothermic process because the adsorption energy (Eads) was negative, and the stability of adsorption was positively correlated with the absolute value of the adsorption energy [38]. For a positive adsorption energy, it was an endothermic process and would be difficult to carry out spontaneously from the perspective of thermodynamics [39]. Results and discussion Crystalline structure and NH3-SCR activity of the catalysts The XRD patterns of the Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 catalyst and intermediate species are presented in Fig. 2 with the major peaks indexed with Miller indices. The diffraction peaks centered at 26.2° and 27.7° assigned to phosphomolybdic acid (PDF 43−0317) were observed in the XRD patterns of HPMo both before and after calcining at 350 ℃ [40]. The diffraction peaks of HPMo (26.2° and 27.7°) and CuO (35.5°, 38.7°, 48.7°, 61.5°, PDF 48–1548) were also observed in the XRD pattern of Cu(3)-HPMo [41]. No obvious diffraction peaks of MoO3 were found in the XRD patterns of HPMo and Cu(3)-HPMo after calcination at 350 ℃, indicating that phosphomolybdic acid did no decompose after calcination. The diffraction peaks of anatase TiO2 (25.3°, 37.8°, 48.0°, 55.0°, 62.7°, PDF 21–1272) were detected in the XRD pattern of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2, while no characteristic peaks of the active component were observed [42]. This may be due to the good dispersion of the active component on the surface of the catalyst. Fig. 3 shows the NH3-SCR activity of HPMo/TiO2, Cu/TiO2 and Cu(x)-HPMo/TiO2(x = 2,3,4) in the temperature range of 150–350 ℃. It is observed that the denitration efficiency of HPMo/TiO2 increased from 28 % to 99.6 % as the temperature increased from 150 ℃ from 250 ℃. A similar trend was observed for the denitration efficiency of other catalysts as shown in Fig. 3. The denitration efficiency of Cu/TiO2 was higher than that of HPMo/TiO2, particularly at the temperatures from 150 ℃ to 250 ℃. As the Cu/Mo molar ratio increased, the activity in this group of the catalysts at the 150−250 °C range followed the order of: Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2>Cu(4)-HPMo/TiO2>Cu(2)-HPMo/TiO2. When the temperature range was 250–350 ℃, the denitration efficiency was above 95 % for all of the samples. Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 exhibited the highest NH3-SCR activity. The denitration efficiency of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 was 82 % at the temperature of 150 ℃ and increased to 99 % at 200 ℃. Effect of SO2 and water vapor on the catalytic activity Effect of SO2 on the catalytic activity The effects of SO2 on the catalytic activity of Cu/TiO2 and Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 were investigated and the results are presented in Fig. 4 . It is observed from Fig. 4(a) that for both Cu/TiO2 and Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2, catalytic activity remained almost unchanged for the SO2 concentrations was 200 ppm. As the SO2 concentration increased from 200 ppm to 400 ppm, the denitration efficiency of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 decreased from 99 % to 95 % while that of Cu/TiO2 decreased from 93 % to 45 %. As the SO2 concentration increased to 600 ppm, the denitration efficiency was 37 % and 28 % for Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 and Cu/TiO2, respectively. After cutting off SO2 in the feed gas, the denitration efficiency of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 and Cu/TiO2 recovered to 84 % and 72 %, respectively. Even though Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 showed better SO2 resistance than Cu/TiO2, the activity of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 was also inhibited as the SO2 concentrations above 400 ppm. Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 with strong surface acidity could suppress the SO2 adsorption on the surface of catalysts. However, the driving force of SO2 diffusion increases with increased SO2 concentration and SO2 in the gas phase diffused more strongly at high concentration than at low concentration. Accordingly, more SO2 molecules reached the surface of the catalysts at the SO2 concentration of 600 ppm than 400 ppm. The catalytic activity of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 in the presence of 600 ppm SO2 was inhibited more severely than it in the presence of 400 ppm SO2. Moreover, for the SO2 in the feed gas of 200 ppm, the denitration efficiency of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 was tested as a function of time and the results are presented in Fig. 4(b). It is observed that the catalytic activity almost didn’t decrease in 650 min. To investigate the influence of surface acidity on the SO2 resistance of catalysts, NH3-TPD profiles of Cu/TiO2 and Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 were obtained and are presented in Fig. 5 . Cu/TiO2 presented a NH3 desorption peak belonging to a medium strong acid near 310 ℃, and Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 showed a continuous NH3 desorption peak from 200 ℃ to 500 ℃. Moreover, the surface acidity of the catalyst can be expressed quantitatively by the desorption peak area [43]. It is observed from Fig. 5 that the desorption peak area of Cu/TiO2 was only 54.79 mmol NH3/g, while that of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 was 144.01 mmol NH3/g. SO2 is an acidic gas and the adsorption of SO2 on the Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 surface may be hindered by its strong surface acidity. Therefore, the SO2 resistance of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 is better than that of Cu/TiO2. Both the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) and Elry-Rideal (E–R) mechanisms indicate that the NH3 molecule was first adsorbed on the acid site (Lewis and Brønsted acids) and then reacts with NO x to form N2 and H2O. Accordingly, the catalyst with strong surface acidity promotes the adsorption of NH3 which is favorable for the NH3-SCR de-NO x performance [44]. FT-IR analysis was conducted after Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 was tested with SO2 in the feed gas (Fig. 6 ). The characteristic peak at 1062 cm−1 was attributed to the stretching vibration peak of P-Oa of the phosphomolybdic acid [45]. The bands at 1635 cm−1 and 3430 cm−1 were ascribed to the stretching vibration peak of −OH and the H–O-H bending vibration peak of water molecules, respectively [46,47]. We note that sulfate species (1120 cm−1) were formed on the catalyst surface as the SO2 concentration increased to 600 ppm [48]. The sulfate species may be ammonium sulfate or a sulfate of the active component. The FT-IR results were consistent with the results of the activity test presented in Fig. 4. To determine the composition of the sulfate species, the TG curves of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 tested with SO2 in the feed gas are presented in Fig. 7 . A mass loss is clearly observed in the temperature range of 50 ℃ to 600 ℃ for two samples. This mass loss can be ascribed to the bound water attached to the of catalyst surface. Ammonium sulfate and ammonium bisulfate decompose at the temperatures of 230 ℃ and 350 °C, respectively [49]. However, no accelerated mass loss was observed for the two samples in the temperature range of 50 ℃ to 600 ℃, indicating the lack of (NH4)2SO4 or NH4HSO4 formation on the surfaces of the samples. In Fig. 7, an accelerated mass loss at the temperature range of 600 ℃ to 650 ℃ was found in the TG curves of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 after it was tested in the feed gas containing 600 ppm SO2. This can be ascribed to the decomposition of copper sulfate (CuSO4→CuO + SO3) [50]. At low SO2 concentration, phosphoromolybdic acid with strong surface acidity can inhibit SO2 adsorption. As SO2 concentration increased to 600 ppm, the SO2 in the gas phase diffused strongly and it reached the catalyst surface. Accordingly, copper sulfate was formed on the catalyst surface by the reaction of SO2 and the active component. The TG results were consistent with the experimental results and FT-IR results. Effect of water vapor on the catalytic activity The effect of water vapor on the SCR performance of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 was compared with that of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2(s), with the results presented in Fig. 8 . The specific surface area of TiO2 of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 is higher than that of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2(s). It is observed that when water vapor concentration was increased from 0 ppm to 4 × 104 ppm, the catalytic activity of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 remained almost constant while that of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2(s) decreased from 90 % to 75 %. As the water vapor concentration increased from 4 × 104 ppm to 8 × 104 ppm, the denitration efficiency of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 decreased from 97 % to 80 % while that of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2(s) was approximately 75 %. BET surface area tests were carried out to investigate the relationship between the water resistance and specific surface area of the catalysts. The BET surface areas of TiO2(s), TiO2, Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2(s) and Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 were 90.46, 322.05, 82.50 and 151.47 m2 g−1, respectively. Based on the BET results, the TiO2 carrier with a large specific surface area may improve the specific surface area of the catalyst. The results of the tests for water resistance show that Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 has better water resistance than Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2(s), which may be related to the fact that Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 with a large specific surface area provided more active sites. Effect of SO2 and water vapor on the catalytic activity The effects of SO2 and water vapor on the catalytic activity of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 were examined in a feed gas containing 500 ppm NO, 500 ppm NH3, 8 × 104 ppm O2, 200 ppm SO2 and 4 × 104 ppm H2O (Fig. 9 ). It is clear that the denitration efficiency remain almost constant within 150 min. Together with the FT-IR and TG, these results indicated that no ammonium sulfate, ammonium bisulfate or copper oxide was deposited on Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 after it was tested in the feed gas containing SO2 and water vapor. DFT calculation Computational models Based on the XRD results, HPMo molecular structure and CuO (1 1 1) supercell were selected as the computational models (Fig. 10 ) [24,51]. The HPMo molecular structure has a terminal O atom (O1), two types of bridging O atoms (O2 and O3) and three types of Mo atoms (Mo1, Mo2 and Mo3). The CuO (1 1 1) supercell has two types of tri-coordinated atoms (O1 and Cu1) and two types of tetra-coordinated atoms (O2 and Cu2). The Lewis acid sites were constructed by the Mo-O bonds and Cu-O bonds, and the Brønsted acid sites were constructed by forming Mo−OH bonds and Cu−OH bonds though the adsorption of H atoms. Adsorption of SO2 on HPMo and CuO (1 1 1) The adsorption of SO2 on the HPMo surface and the corresponding adsorption energy are shown in Fig. 11 . When SO2 was adsorbed on the O atom of the HPMo molecule with the S atom as the endpoint, the absolute values of the adsorption energy on different sites were in the order of O3 > O2 > O1. This indicated that SO2 is more likely to be adsorbed on the O3 position. When SO2 was adsorbed on the Lewis acid site (Mo-O) of the HPMo molecule with the S atom as the endpoint, the absolute value of the adsorption energies on different sites were in the order of Mo2 > Mo3 > Mo1. SO2 is more likely to be adsorbed on the Mo2 site. When SO2 was adsorbed on the Brønsted acid site (Mo−OH) of the HPMo molecule with the S atom as the endpoint, the absolute values of the adsorption energy on different sites were in the order of O3-H > O1-H > O2-H. Therefore, SO2 is more likely to be adsorbed on the O3-H site. The absolute values of the adsorption energies of SO2 adsorbed on HPMo were less than 42 kJ mol−1, indicating that these adsorptions were attributed to physical adsorption and chemical bonds were not formed [52]. Fig. 12 shows the adsorption of SO2 on the CuO (1 1 1) surface. The adsorption energies of SO2 adsorbed on O and Cu site were negative and their absolute value all greater than 300 kJ mol−1. The adsorption energies of SO2 on the O1 (-357.76 kJ mol−1) and O2 (-350.82 kJ mol−1) sites were nearly equal. For the SO2 adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites (Cu-O bond), the adsorption energy of SO2 on the Cu1 site (-346.81 kJ mol−1) was slightly higher than that on the Cu2 site (-301.05 kJ mol−1). However, the energies of SO2 adsorption on the Brønsted acid sites (Cu−OH) were only approximately −37 kJ mol−1, and were attributed to physical adsorption. Partial density of states (PDOS) provides a more accurate understanding of the interaction between gas molecules and adsorbed substrates [53]. Fig. 13 shows the PDOS spectra of the S, O, Cu and H atoms when SO2 is adsorbed on the O1, Cu1 and O1-H sites of CuO (1 1 1). In the valence band near Fermi energy level, H atom, O atom, S atom and Cu atom respectively contributed 1s, 2p, 3p and 3d orbitals [54]. The S3p orbital and O2p orbital exhibit resonances at approximately -8.0 eV and -3.6 eV when the SO2 molecule was adsorbed on the O1 site, indicating that hybrid bonds occurred between the S atom and the O atom. Similarly, when the SO2 molecule was adsorbed on the Cu1 site, the resonance peaks of the S3p orbital and Cu3d orbital also appeared close to -6.5 eV and -4.2 eV, further indicating that SO2 formed stable chemical bonds on the O and Cu atoms of CuO (1 1 1). In addition, the PDOS of the S and H atoms on the Brønsted acid sites showed, only a slight resonance at -8.4 eV. Considering this result together with the adsorption energy of SO2 on the O1-H site (-38.52 kJ mol−1), it is concluded that the SO2 molecule cannot be adsorbed on the Brønsted acid site on the surface of CuO (1 1 1) in a stable manner. Adsorption of H2O on HPMo and CuO (1 1 1) The adsorption the of H2O molecule on the HPMo surface and the corresponding adsorption energy are shown in Fig. 14 . When H2O was adsorbed on the O atom of the HPMo molecule with H atom as the endpoint, the absolute value of the adsorption energy on the different sites was in the order of O3 > O2 > O1. The adsorption of H2O on the O1 site was attributed to physical adsorption. When H2O was adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites (Mo-O) of the HPMo molecule with the O atom as the endpoint, the absolute value of the adsorption energy on different sites was in the order of Mo3 > Mo1 > Mo2. Clearly, the adsorption energy of H2O on the Mo3 site was significantly higher than that on the other two sites. When H2O was adsorbed on the Brønsted acid sites (Mo−OH) of the HPMo molecule with the O atom as the endpoint, the absolute values of the adsorption energy on different sites were in the order of O2-H > O1-H > O3-H. Generally, the H2O molecule can form stable chemical adsorption on the Mo-O and Mo−OH sites, and the adsorption capacity of H2O on the Brønsted acid sites was stronger than that on the other sites. Fig. 15 shows the adsorption of H2O on the CuO (1 1 1) surface. The absolute values of the H2O adsorption energies on the O and Cu sites of CuO (1 1 1) were greater than −250 kJ mol−1. This indicated that H2O can be stably adsorbed on CuO (1 1 1). The H2O adsorption energies on the O1 and Cu1 sites were higher than that on the O2 and Cu2 sites, indicating that the strong interaction between the tri-coordinated atoms and water molecules was likely to occur. However, the adsorption energy of H2O was only approximately −130 kJ mol−1 on the Brønsted acid sites (Cu−OH), which was significantly lower than those on other sites. The bonding of the H2O molecule adsorbed on HPMo and CuO (1 1 1) was analyzed using PDOS (Figs. 16 and 17 ). When the H2O molecule was adsorbed on the O3 site of the HPMo molecule, the H1s and O2p orbitals formed hybrid resonance peaks at -5.7 eV and -1.8 eV. On the Mo3 site, the O2p and Mo3d orbitals formed resonance peaks at -6.0 eV and -2.0 eV. When the H2O molecule was adsorbed on the Brønsted acid site (O2-H), the H1s and O2p orbitals showed only one resonance peak at -8.6 eV. On the CuO (1 1 1) surface, when the H2O molecule was adsorbed on the O1 site, the H1s and O2p orbitals formed two resonance peaks at -8.5 eV and -6.0 eV, indicating that H–O bonds were formed on the O1 site. The Cu3d and O2p orbitals formed resonance peaks at -9.5 eV, -6.1 eV, -5.0 eV and -2.5 eV on the Cu1 site, indicating a strong interaction between H2O and CuO (1 1 1) due to the formation of the Cu-O bond, consistent with the adsorption energy calculation results. When H2O was adsorbed on the Brønsted acid site (O2-H), only one resonance peak of the H1s and O2p orbitals was found at -7.8 eV, and hydrogen bonding occurred between the O atom of H2O and the H atom on the Brønsted acid site of CuO (1 1 1). Competitive adsorption of NO, NH3, SO2 and H2O on the catalyst surface In the NH3-SCR de-NO x process, NH3 molecules were adsorbed on the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites on the catalyst surface to form coordinated NH3 or NH4 +, while some NO molecules were adsorbed on the O atom or metal atom site of the catalyst. The competitive co-adsorption of the reactant (NH3 and NO) with SO2 and water vapor was observed on the catalyst surface [55]. Six active sites were selected from HPMo and CuO (1 1 1) and the adsorption energies of different gases on these sites were calculated (Tables 1 and 2 ). Table 1 shows the adsorption energies of NO, NH3 and SO2 on the surface of HPMo and CuO (1 1 1). On the HPMo surface, the adsorption energies of SO2 on the O3, Mo2 and O3-H sites were less than -42 kJ mol−1. The adsorption energies of NO on the O3 and Mo2 sites were -98.08 kJ mol−1 and -92.11 kJ mol−1. The adsorption energies of NH3 on the Mo2 and O3-H sites were -80.48 kJ mol−1 and -199.11 kJ mol−1, respectively. The competitive adsorption capacity of SO2 on HPMo surface was weaker than that of NO and NH3. On the CuO (1 1 1) surface, the adsorption capacity of SO2 on the O1 site was stronger than that of NO, while the adsorption capacity on the Cu1 site was similar to that of NO and NH3. The NH3-TPD results (Fig. 5) indicated that the surface acidity of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 was stronger that of Cu/TiO2. SO2 is an acidic gas and the adsorption of SO2 on the the catalyst surface will be hindered by increasing surface acidity of the catalyst [15,16]. The DFT results were consistent with the results of the characterization (Figs. 5–7) and experiments (Figs. 4 and 9). The adsorption energies of NO, NH3 and H2O on the surface of HPMo and CuO are shown in Table 2. It is clear that the reactants (NO and NH3) were more likely to adsorb on the O3 and O2-H sites of HPMo than H2O. However, H2O adsorption on the Mo3 site was more stable than that of NH3. The reactants (NO and NH3) were more likely to adsorb on the Cu1 and O1-H sites than H2O, while H2O adsorption on the O1 site was more stable than that of NO. It could be concluded from Table 2 that even though H2O can be adsorbed on the Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 surface, the adsorption of the reactants was more stable on Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 more stable than that of H2O. The results of the calculations were further confirmed by the experiments as discussed in section 3.2.2. Structure speculation of active components The nanoscale morphology of the Cu(3)-HPMo was obtained by FE-SEM and HRTEM observation, with the obtained images shown in Fig. 18 . It is clearly observed that the globular core was surrounded by a sheet-like shell, forming a typical core-shell structure. It was previously reported that HPW can act as the protective shell of CeO2 to reduce the influence of SO2 in the denitration process [56]. Considering the results of experiments, characterizations and DFT calculation, it could be speculated that the active component Cu(3)-HPMo was the core-shell structure with CuO as the core and HPMo wrapped around as the shell. The NO and NH3 can pass through the spaces between the HPMo molecules, and the SCR is carried out both on the shell and on the core of Cu-HPMo/TiO2. The shell with a strong surface acidity inhibits the SO2 adsorption on the Cu-HPMo/TiO2 surface. FT-IR results indicated there was no sulfate on the Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 surface tested at 200 ℃ in the presence of 200 ppm SO2 and 4 × 104 ppm H2O. SO2 in the gas phase diffused more strongly at the concentration of 600 ppm than at 200 ppm. Accordingly, SO2 could reach the core of Cu-HPMo/TiO2 as the SO2 concentration increased to 600 ppm, thereby degrading the SCR performance of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2. The FT-IR and TG spectra of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 indicated that CuSO4 was formed as the SO2 concentration was increased to 600 ppm. This mechanism can provide a reasonable explanation for the function of HPMo and CuO in the core-shell structure of Cu-HPMo/TiO2. Conclusions In this work, a novel catalyst Cu-HPMo/TiO2 for low temperature SCR was developed. The activity test results showed that the denitration efficiency of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 was approximately 82 % at 150 ℃ and increased to nearly 99 % at 200 ℃. Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 with strong surface acidity suppressed the SO2 adsorption and showed good SO2 resistance for the SO2 concentrations below 400 ppm. SO2 in the gas phase diffused more strongly at high concentration than at low concentration. The catalytic activity of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 was degraded by SO2 and the FT-IR and TG results indicated that copper sulfate was formed as the SO2 concentration increased to 600 ppm. Increasing the specific surface area enhanced the amount of the active sites unoccupied by water vapor and improved the H2O resistance of the catalyst. The catalytic activity of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 was approximately 98 % as the water vapor concentration changed from 0 ppm to 4 × 104 ppm. However, the catalytic activity of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 was clearly inhibited for the water vapor concentration above 4 × 104 ppm. The adsorption of SO2 and H2O on the surface of Cu-HPMo/TiO2 was investigated by DFT calculation. The results showed that SO2 was only physically adsorbed on the surface of HPMo. However, SO2 was chemically adsorbed on the CuO (1 1 1) surface (other than Brønsted acid sites). Water vapor can be adsorbed on the Cu-HPMo/TiO2 surface to form hydroxyl (Mo−OH, Cu−OH), which was beneficial for the NH3 adsorption in the SCR process. Analysis of the competitive gas adsorption showed that the adsorption energies of SO2 and H2O on the HPMo surface were generally weaker than those of NH3 and NO. The core-shell structure of the active components (CuO was the core, and HPMo was the shell) was speculated. This structure is related to the good resistance to SO2 and water vapor of Cu-HPMo/TiO2. coredata.dc:description: The selective catalytic reduction with NH3 (NH3-SCR) catalyst for de-NO x is usually inhibited by SO2 and water vapor at low temperature. The copper-doped phosphomolybdic acid (Cu-HPMo) was supported on titanium dioxide (TiO2) and a novel catalyst Cu-HPMo/TiO2 with good resistance to SO2 and water vapor was developed. Experimental results show that the best catalytic activity of Cu-HPMo/TiO2 was obtained at the Cu/Mo molar ratio of 3. The denitration efficiency over the Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 catalyst was approximately 99 % at 200 ℃ and remained almost constant in the presence of 200 ppm SO2 and 4 × 104 ppm H2O. Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 with strong surface acidity suppressed SO2 adsorption and showed good SO2 resistance. SO2 in the gas phase diffused more strongly at the concentration of 600 ppm than at 400 ppm. The catalytic activity of Cu(3)-HPMo/TiO2 decreased in the presence of 600 ppm of SO2 and the FT-IR and TG results indicated that copper sulfate was formed. Density functional theory (DFT) calculation was used to study the adsorption states of SO2 and H2O on the catalyst surface, and the results indicated that SO2 could not form chemical adsorption on the HPMo surface. Based on the results of experiments, characterization and DFT calculation, the core-shell structure of active components was speculated. This structure was related to the anti-sulfur and anti-water properties of Cu-HPMo/TiO2.
coredata.dc:title: Investigation of SO2 and H2O poisoning over Cu-HPMo/TiO2 catalyst for Low temperature SCR: An experimental and DFT study
